user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_post_process:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_post_process (struct MHD_PostProcessor *pp,
                  const char *post_data,
                  size_t post_data_len)
{
  if (0 == post_data_len)
    return MHD_YES;
  if (NULL == pp)
    return MHD_NO;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ (MHD_HTTP_POST_ENCODING_FORM_URLENCODED,
                                 pp->encoding,
                                 MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (
                                   MHD_HTTP_POST_ENCODING_FORM_URLENCODED)))
    return post_process_urlencoded (pp,
                                    post_data,
                                    post_data_len);
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ (MHD_HTTP_POST_ENCODING_MULTIPART_FORMDATA,
                                 pp->encoding,
                                 MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (
                                   MHD_HTTP_POST_ENCODING_MULTIPART_FORMDATA)))
    return post_process_multipart (pp,
                                   post_data,
                                   post_data_len);
  /* this should never be reached */
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ (MHD_HTTP_POST_ENCODING_FORM_URLENCODED,
                                 pp->encoding,
                                 MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (
                                   MHD_HTTP_POST_ENCODING_FORM_URLENCODED)))
    return post_process_urlencoded (pp,
                                    post_data,
                                    post_data_len);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.14 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment calls a length-limited helper (MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_) with an explicit static length (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_), not the standard memcmp on null-terminated strings. There is no direct use of memcmp to compare null-terminated strings in this fragment.
